topics.summary_text: The concept of a limit describes the value a function approaches as the input approaches some number. It formalizes the idea of approaching but not necessarily reaching a point.
One-sided limits focus on the behavior of a function as the input approaches a number from the left or from the right. If both sides agree, the two-sided limit exists.
The definition of continuity requires that a function be defined at a point, the limit exists at that point, and the function’s value equals that limit.
The derivative measures instantaneous rate of change. Formally it is defined as f’(x) = lim(h→0)[f(x+h) – f(x)] / h.
Derivatives can be interpreted as the slope of the tangent line to a curve at a point, representing how steeply the function is changing.
